3444.76.text: you know, what the new date is and to make that change in a nontransparent way.

3453.18.text: the markets and the business community can make that calculation on their own

3458.55.text: and adjust that-their estimates of when rates will begin to increase based only

3466.78.text: on their own forecast and not have to wait

3468.86.text: for the Federal Open Market Committee to give them a date.

3472.08.text: So we just think it's a better approach.

3480.55.text: Mr. Chairman, Josh Zumbrun, Bloomberg News.

3482.87.text: By mid-2015, the recovery is going to be nearly six years old.

3486.39.text: The average postwar recovery has been a little less than five.

3490.10.text: We're already banking on a very long expansion.

3493.26.text: You expect, by mid-2015, the funds rate is going to be at zero percent,

3496.72.text: your balance sheet is potentially at $4 trillion.

3499.75.text: If the business cycle runs out of steam and you're still

3504.32.text: does the Fed no longer have a forceful response in that situation?

3510.08.text: Well, the Fed will always, you know, keep-we've innovated quite a bit

3515.86.text: in the last few years and it's always possible we could find new ways

3519.38.text: to provide support for the economy.

3521.49.text: But it's certainly true, I've-you know,

3524.24.text: there's no doubt that with interest rates near zero

3528.17.text: and with the balance sheet already large,

3531.65.text: that the ability to provide additional accommodation is not unlimited

3535.66.text: and that that's just a reality and that actually is an argument, I think,

3539.41.text: for being a little bit more aggressive now.

3540.97.text: I mean, it's a really good objective to get the economy moving,

3545.92.text: to get some momentum that protects the economy against unanticipated shocks

3550.91.text: that might occur, and gets us off the zero bound earlier.

3558.65.text: the kind of risks that arise when the-when policy interest rates are close

3563.28.text: to zero, and the greater difficulty in providing additional policy support,

3568.11.text: I think that's an argument for being somewhat more proactive now,

3572.50.text: when we still have the ability to do that, and to try to get the economy,

3577.42.text: you know, back to a healthy condition.

3588.14.text: My question pertains to the Volcker Rule.

3590.32.text: Regulators, earlier this year, seemed cautiously optimistic that they'd be able

3593.89.text: to finalize a rule by the end of the year.

3596.17.text: However, that seems a bit unlikely at this point.

3598.83.text: And now, as you know, lawmakers are calling

3600.92.text: for a two-year implementation delay on the rule.

3603.99.text: Given the fact that it's been such a lengthy process,

3606.35.text: can you tell us where things stand at this point?

3609.20.text: How much closer are we to a final rule?

3611.87.text: Have the agencies been able to work out their differences?

3615.08.text: And, if you may, a prediction on when we might actually see a rule.

3619.64.text: We've made quite a bit of progress.

3621.03.text: It's a difficult, complex rule, as you know, and we've had, I think I recall,

3629.25.text: So it's been a lot to look at.

3631.56.text: There are a lot of concerns that arose even from, you know,

3635.81.text: foreign commenters about the effects on their bond markets, et cetera.

3640.12.text: So there's been a lot of work to do.

3642.76.text: There, I think there is quite a bit of agreement,

3645.10.text: I wouldn't say a final agreement,

3646.28.text: but quite a bit of agreement

3647.46.text: on key points among the regulators, at this juncture.

3651.62.text: And, of course, if Congress gives us some other instruction, we'll follow that,

3656.63.text: but so far, we haven't received any different instruction.

3659.46.text: So it's our intent to try to get this done early in 2013.

3668.53.text: Peter Barnes, Fox Business, Mr. Chairman.

3670.98.text: Since your last press conference with us, we've had an election.

3674.46.text: One of the candidates in that election, Governor Romney,

3677.07.text: said that he would not reappoint you to a third term as Chairman.

3681.22.text: President Obama did not weigh in on the issue but he was-he did win reelection.

3686.35.text: If the President were to call you and say, "Ben,

3693.10.text: your country needs your continued stewardship at the Federal Reserve.

3698.27.text: We need you to stay and finish the job, see this through."

3705.10.text: Would you do it, and, by chance, have you had any conversations to that effect

3709.62.text: with the President or anybody on his team?

3713.74.text: So to answer the last part, no, I haven't had any conversations.

3716.99.text: I think the President has got quite a few issues he needs to be thinking about,

3721.80.text: from fiscal cliff to many other appointments and so on.

3724.81.text: From my own perspective, I just, I really don't have anything to add

3732.00.text: I am very much engaged in these difficult issues that we're discussing today,

3736.16.text: and I have not been spending time thinking about my own future.

3741.28.text: So I don't really have anything to add there.

3753.50.text: The two questions, taking the Goldfarb rule into effect,

3757.80.text: one having to do with the CPI,

3759.20.text: there's a lot of debate now with the Boehner plan about this chained CPI.

3762.19.text: As an econ-not as a Fed Chairman

3764.08.text: but as an economist-is there a logic in going to that?

3766.88.text: Do you think it's a move that should be done separate from the politics of it?

3772.49.text: And again, with your economist hat, the labor market,

3775.24.text: you talked about the importance, not looking at the 6.5 percent threshold,

3780.27.text: A big debate-Steve Liesman's nemesis talks a lot

3783.43.text: about people being beamed to Mars.

3785.22.text: In your mind, what is happening in the job market?

3789.34.text: Is that why it's coming down

3790.84.text: or is it because people-the degree of discouraged workers?

3793.60.text: What is your sense of how quickly it's fallen because of new employment?

3801.56.text: So, on the first question, the chained CPI

3804.93.text: versus the fixed weight CPI is a technical issue.

3809.09.text: The chained CPI is technically better, according to most economists,

3812.95.text: because it allows for changes in the mix of goods

3816.54.text: and services that people actually consume more effectively.

3821.42.text: However, whether, you know, whether that's more appropriate for, say,

3827.33.text: Social Security indexing or not, I think that's ultimately a political decision.

3831.89.text: I suppose a rejoinder would be

3834.43.text: that neither the CPI nor the chained CPI may necessarily be a particularly good

3838.67.text: measure of the cost of living for Social Security recipients.

3842.30.text: So, those are the kinds of questions

3844.25.text: that Congress is going to have to deal with.

3850.65.text: Second part of your question was?

3854.43.text: The debate over the extent to which the unemployment rate is falling from-

3862.20.text: Yes. Well, you know, you can see the comparison by looking, for example,

3869.47.text: at the household survey, which gives estimates of how many people are added

3877.38.text: to the labor force, how many are added to the employed,

3880.61.text: how many people are leaving the labor force,

3882.55.text: and it's true that part of the decline in unemployment-and indeed all of it

3886.49.text: in the last reading, but over the recovery,

3890.08.text: part of the decline in unemployment has come from declines

3894.34.text: in participation rates, that is, people leaving the labor force.

3898.34.text: Some of that decline in participation appears to be due to longer-run factors,

3905.62.text: aging and changing patterns of work among women.

3910.70.text: So those things were probably not directly related

3917.69.text: But beyond that downward trend, there's been some additional decline

3920.59.text: in labor force participation, and in the ratio of employment to population,

3925.31.text: which presumably is linked to discouragement about the state of the labor force.

3932.53.text: So that certainly is part of the issue.

3935.34.text: That being said, obviously there has been a good bit of job creation.

3939.05.text: You can see that either in the household survey

3941.82.text: or in the payroll establishment survey.

3947.32.text: So I think there's no doubt that the labor market is considerably better today

3954.77.text: than it was two years ago, there's not any question about that.

3959.30.text: But it's also the case that many indicators

3962.64.text: of the labor market remain quite weak,

3966.59.text: ranging from the number of long-term unemployed to the number of people

3969.81.text: who have part-time work who would like full-time work.

3973.88.text: Wage growth obviously is very weak, and I could go on.

3982.68.text: So, it may be that the labor market is even a bit weaker

3988.24.text: than the current unemployment rate suggests,

3990.02.text: but I think that it is nevertheless the case that there has been improvement

3995.18.text: since the trough a couple of years ago.

4003.36.text: Mr. Chairman, Catherine Hollander from National Journal.

4006.27.text: How concerned are you that markets will have to tank in order to get lawmakers

4009.88.text: to reach a deal on the fiscal cliff,

4011.78.text: and what do you make of their recent complacency?

4014.14.text: Is there a Wall Street-Washington disconnect?

4019.98.text: Well, I certainly hope that markets won't have to tank.

4022.56.text: I don't-we want to have confidence, not just in markets but in businesses

4029.04.text: and households as well, and the best way the fiscal policymakers can achieve

4035.77.text: that is by coming to a solution as quickly as possible.

4046.00.text: Markets have obviously already responded to some extent, up and down;

4049.85.text: you can see from day to day how they respond to news about the negotiations.

4056.15.text: But on the other hand, it's also true, if you look at the experience,

4060.40.text: I think the very informative experience of the debt limit debate in August

4065.28.text: of 2011, that both confidence and markets remain pretty sanguine

4075.69.text: up to pretty close to the point where it looked

4078.24.text: like there was actually a chance the debt limit would not be raised.

4084.04.text: And then, of course, there was a pretty sharp shock, particularly to confidence,

4089.58.text: about the time of the, you know, of the final debates.

4098.98.text: So it's not unusual to see markets being complacent.

4105.82.text: Of course, there's from a market point of view,

4109.33.text: there are sort of risks in both directions.

4112.09.text: Obviously, things go badly, but perhaps if things go especially well,

4115.41.text: that would be good news, and maybe right now markets are sort

4118.97.text: of taking an average of those two possibilities.

4121.46.text: But again, just to reiterate, I don't think any policymaker, including the Fed,

4131.68.text: What we should be doing is making policy, you know, based on the fundamentals

4138.58.text: and doing what's best for the economy

4141.10.text: and I hope that fiscal policymakers will follow that injunction as well.

4154.71.text: Mr. Chairman, Steve Beckner of Market News International.

4158.13.text: With the federal government borrowing roughly $1 trillion a year

4162.87.text: and now with the Fed on pace to buy roughly a trillion dollars a year in bonds,

4171.05.text: are you concerned about a public, and possibly global,

4174.93.text: perception that the Fed is accommodating not just growth

4182.04.text: and are you concerned about what this might do to the Fed's credibility,

4186.85.text: and the credibility of U.S. finances in general,

4190.59.text: and the credibility of the dollar as the world's leading currency?

4195.71.text: Well, first of all, just a couple of facts.

4200.44.text: The-we're buying Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities,

4208.04.text: So we're buying considerably less than the Treasury is issuing and, moreover,

4215.09.text: the share of outstanding Treasuries that the Federal Reserve owns is not all

4218.88.text: that different from what it was before the crisis,

4221.19.text: because while our holdings have increased,

4223.10.text: so has the-obviously the stock of Treasuries in public hands.

4227.56.text: So it's not quite evident that there has been such a radical shift there.

4232.69.text: You know, we've been increasing our balance sheet now for some time,

4236.25.text: and we've been very clear that this is a temporary measure.

4241.38.text: It's a way to provide additional accommodation

4244.97.text: to an economy which needs support.

4247.16.text: We've been equally clear that we will normalize the balance sheet,

4250.43.text: that we will reduce the size of our holdings and-whether by letting them run off

4255.74.text: or by selling assets in the future.

4260.24.text: So this is, again, only a temporary step.

4262.56.text: It would be quite a different matter if we were buying these assets

4275.89.text: We are very clear about our intentions.

4278.37.text: And I think up until now, it seems our credibility has been quite good.

4285.09.text: There is not any sign either of current inflation

4288.75.text: or of any-there's no strong evidence that there are any increases

4293.25.text: in inflation expectations for that matter, looking at financial markets,

4296.69.text: looking at surveys, looking at economic forecasts, and so on.

4301.66.text: So, this is one of the things that we have to look at.

4304.43.text: Remember, I talked earlier about the potential costs of a large balance sheet.

4308.55.text: We want to be sure that there's no misunderstanding,

4312.65.text: that there's no effect on inflation expectations

4315.45.text: from the size of our balance sheet.

4316.49.text: That's one of the things we have to look at, but as to this point,

4322.10.text: there just really is no evidence that people are taking it that way.

4326.43.text: And I guess it's worth pointing out-of course we've been very focused

4329.67.text: on the United States here, but we're not the only central bank

4333.79.text: that has increased the size of its balance sheet.

4336.00.text: The Japanese, the Europeans, the British have all done the same,

4340.71.text: and very much more or less to the same extent in terms of the fraction of GDP,

4345.58.text: and I think the sophisticated market players and the public understand

4351.72.text: that this is part of a collective need,

4355.79.text: a need to provide additional accommodation to weak economies

4360.14.text: and not an accommodation of fiscal policy.

4370.08.text: Last but not least, Greg Robb, MarketWatch.

4373.78.text: There seems to be growing evidence that some of the MBS purchases,

4378.42.text: the impact of the MBS purchases, are that banks are holding on to some

4382.96.text: of the gains and not passing them on to the borrowers.

4386.09.text: Is there anything you can do about that and are you concerned about that?

4390.61.text: So the question is-just to restate your question-is about the spread

4396.37.text: between the mortgage rates that the public pays and the yields

4400.59.text: to mortgage-backed securities that banks may hold, and the question is,

4405.91.text: is that spread widening so that the full benefit of the reduction

4412.74.text: in MBS yields is not being passed through, that's the question.

4415.87.text: Well, I have to make sure everybody heard it, so you could answer.

4423.09.text: Our analysis suggests that it takes time-two points.

4431.49.text: The first point is that while we don't expect a hundred percent pass-through

4437.52.text: of MBS yields to mortgage rates,

4440.77.text: our empirical and theoretical analysis-and we've had quite a bit of work done

4446.08.text: on this issue-suggests that over time, the great majority of the decline

4451.98.text: in MBS yields does get passed through to mortgage rates.

4457.53.text: So we do anticipate, over time, that the full benefit will,

4464.33.text: or most of the benefit will, be seen by retail customers.

4468.38.text: And indeed, we have seen already a pretty significant decline

4471.31.text: since September in retail mortgage rates.

4474.85.text: But one thing that's perhaps confusing this issue a little bit is

4480.32.text: that there are other things happening in the economy

4484.93.text: So, for example, there are capacity limitations, which are allowing banks to,

4493.54.text: you know, to charge higher yields, there's extra costs like concerns

4502.32.text: So there's a number of things happening in the economy which will tend,

4506.22.text: all else equal, to raise that spread between mortgage rates

4510.82.text: and MBS yields, so that's unfortunate.

4514.08.text: What we can try to do there, of course, is to try to encourage good policy,

4519.74.text: for example, on putbacks, that will reduce the perceived risk

4523.53.text: and cost to the banks of making mortgage loans.

4528.18.text: But again, you know, I think most of those things, like g-fees, for example,

4534.19.text: are not really in our control, but, again, taking all those issues as constant,

4540.65.text: it does seem to be the case that, over a period of time, not immediately,

4544.60.text: but over a period of time, most of the declines in MBS yields do find their way

4548.74.text: through to mortgage customers and thereby strengthen the housing market.
